comments.commentBody: Mr. Walker, you are probably correct. And if you look at the electoral maps for the presidential elections of 2008 and 2012 you will note that both of the regions that you describe were not only virtually all red, but they were irrelevant to the results of those elections. If people in those regions want to keep fighting a battle that has already been lost at the national level, that is certainly their right, irrespective of the fact that their states will remain irrelevant in deciding national elections for the foreseeable future.

Many of us who are Republicans, Tea party Republicans, Libertarians, Conservatives, (and some who are Democrats) are greedy and power hungry. We believe that we are the entitled ones.
It is by the luck of the draw and because of the problems in our economic model that some of us are unreasonably wealthy; not because we are genetically superior.
The fact is that our Tree of Liberty is being poisoned to its roots by the love of money for money's sake, the love of power and control over others for the sake of demeaning others, and the love of self for the sake of feeling superior to others.
We need to:
-Genuinely love our neighbors and our selves.
-Increase taxes on unreasonably wealthy corporations and individuals.
-Use some of the resulting revenue to pay off the debt and develop economic opportunities in America.
-Use some of the resulting revenue so that poverty will be eliminated and every one of us can have sufficient incomes and live healthy lives here in America.
-Provide education for everyone so that the wealthiest and the least wealthy among us can learn how to responsibly manage our incomes, including disposable income.

Those of us who are wealthy will still be very wealthy, just not unreasonably wealthy.

Our consciences will be clearer. We will behave more constructively with one another. Very few Americans, will act in ways to cause another American's life to be worthless.
Our greed is unhealthy our children and other living things.

The enemy is us.

Shame on them and all the others of us, corporations, individuals, all the others that evade paying taxes, causing destructiveness to the poverty stricken, and to those who are struggling to get by, as well as to the nation's infrastructures.
Tax avoidance as well as tax laws based on selfishness and greed create pain, heartache, and serious illnesses, as well as horribly stressful conditions for other people.
No one needs obscene and totally unnecessary amounts of money. And without obscene and unnecessary amounts, there still would be some of us who live noticeable luxurious existences.
It is clear that this greediness, so basic to human nature, - - but capable of being controlled and eventually bred out of us - causes the aforementioned horrid conditions of illness, dying and death.
Consequently, since these are the facts, and we know these as the facts they are, we are committing a crime against humanity, as "crime against humanity" is defined.
Insuring that no household has less than $40 thousand American dollars is the way to go. And this economic plan would regularly stimulate the American economy.
Of course, we, the wealthiest households and those households with $40 thousand, would need lessons in developing and each week managing effective realistic and frugal budgets. Of course, if people physically could, and the work for pay or as volunteers existed, oh, by the way, being a parent is work, all adults would be doing some kind of this work.

Regarding OSHA data, worker/employee labor effort, (in addition to worker/employee safety), - - provides the American people with the opportunity to look at what the physical energy expenditures, the physical strains, and the physical dangers of each type of job are for worker/employees.
And, with this information, we should evaluate the relationships of energy, strain, and danger to income/salary.
From doing this kind of assessment we would learn and have the evidence that American workers/employees are rather underpaid.
Then we could see to it that salary/income is properly increased, or decreased, to match the energy expended, physical strain.
Increasing salary/income would lead to a more vibrant economy, a well-funded federal budget, and the reduction of the amount of poverty and marginal incomes, - - these things, if we also decide on reasonable amounts of profits, (not outlandish amounts of profits), in terms of what businesses of all sizes need to have to develop business structures, and what executive officers and investors need in order to lead sufficiently opulent life styles for the investments and efforts.
OSHA can provide us with the evidence to objectify the worker/employee in relationship to the employer/corporate-entity in relationship to the salary/income in relationship to personal wealth/capital gains.

As a reformist and an elementary school teacher I have a little bit of a different perspective. When students are first learning to add and subtract, when they are introduced to the standard algorithm too early (before they have an understanding of the properties of the operation or of our base-10 number system), they throw out all of their thinking because they think the algorithm is the 'right' way or the 'grown up' way. It stops the thinking and reasoning they started.
Once students have had a chance to develop these understandings and are comfortable with a variety of sound approaches, it makes perfect sense to do a study of the algorithms and do as you say above. When students are comfortable with the operation and then learn of this efficient method, they usually aren't very thrown off or surprised, but they can make sense of it. Then it becomes one of a number of possibilities when a student is faced with a problem.
So I agree that it is not an "either/or" and that the false dichotomy is quite destructive to mathematics education in this country. But I do think a "when" question is significant.

Obama has always had a centrist agenda in a highly polarized moment in American politics, much to the surprise of many of those who voted for him.

Americans on the liberal side demanded immediate exit from two wars, single payer health insurance, an end to domestic surveillance, much higher taxes on the wealthy, increased government spending and dramatic action on climate changing sectors of the economy.

Americans on the conservative side demand aggressive foreign intervention and military expansion, privatizing the current government role in health care, more surveillance, even fewer taxes and less domestic spending, elimination of the IRS and promoting greater carbon consumption.

The middle ground is pretty small these days, so a centrist leader is not going to be winning a lot of popularity contests. But by this point in their 2nd term, most Presidents are more concerned with the long view, which tends to favor leading from the middle (as FDR did for most of his 4 terms).

Made a move to a much smaller employer. The new plan is much more expensive to me than the old.  Some of it is the direct fees by the plan administrato which I suspect are a function of size.  But, the worst thing is that the investment selections include rebranded versions of index funds with much higher expenses.  The rebranded funds can be matched to the underlying fund by looking at the subadvisors.  The difference between the two fees is extra compensation to the broker.  The impolite way to say that is deceit and fraud.

Getting clear information on what will be billed and what your insurance will allow seems impossible. I used to believe that my insurer paid the same amount to any provider that gave me the same service - utterly wrong as it turns out.

It seems that there is a lot of consolidation - really selling out - on the part of many medical practices. This leaves me with exactly the same doctor and the same appointment but at a dramatically higher price.

My doctor's practice group would charge $170 for a short appointment. My insurer would allow about $80 (so I pay $80). This practice group now merged with another and this is what was billed:
appointment $170 (like before), $85 (not clear for what) and $5 (ditto). My insurer (same insurer same plan) allowed $170 out of the $170 and $65 and $5 so $240 (which I have to pay). This is THREE times what I paid just a few months ago. Same doctor, same appointment.

Something is very very wrong.

Most Americans have unrealistic beliefs about anything "nuclear." For example, NMR [Nuclear Magnetic Resonance] had to be renamed MRI [Magnetic Resonance Imaging] to get sick people into the scanner. It is the exact same machine. Only the sign has been changed. Apparently, the average American doesn't know that all matter, including people, is made of atoms and that atoms have nuclei. The NMR/MRI machine aligns the spins of the nucleons in the atoms in the patient using a big magnet. Since different atoms have different nuclear spin resonances, the NMR/MRI machine can see one element at a time.
